revisions.rev:
The '''Florida Gators football''' team represents the [[University of Florida]] in the sport of [[American football]]. The University of Florida fielded its first official [[varsity team|varsity]] football team in the fall of [[1906 Florida Gators football team|1906]], and has fielded a team every season since then, with the exception of [[1943 Florida Gators football team|1943]]. During the 1990s, the Gators competed in [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I-A]] of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) and the Eastern Division of the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC). They played their home games at [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]] (formerly known as Florida Field) on the university's [[Gainesville, Florida]] campus.
This article includes a game-by-game list of the Florida Gators' ten football seasons from 1990 to 1999. During the 1990s, the Gators were coached by [[Steve Spurrier|Stephen O. "Steve" Spurrier]] (1990–2001), who led the Gators to six SEC championships, one consensus national championship and an overall win-loss record of 122–27–1 (.817).

== 1990 ==
{{Infobox NCAA team season | Year = 1990 | Team = Florida Gators | Conference = Southeastern Conference | ShortConference = SEC | CoachRank = | APRank = 12 | Record = 9–2 | ConfRecord = 6–1 1st* | HeadCoach = [[Steve Spurrier]] | OffCoach = Steve Spurrier | DefCoach = [[Jim Bates (American football coach)|Jim Bates]] | OScheme = | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]] }} {{1990 SEC football standings}}
=== Season overview ===
The [[1990 college football season]] marked the return of the Gators' [[Heisman Trophy]]-winning [[quarterback]] [[Steve Spurrier]] to his [[alma mater]] as the new [[head coach]] of the [[Florida Gators football]] team.<ref name=carlson104126>Norm Carlson, ''University of Florida Football Vault: The History of the Florida Gators'', Whitman Publishing, LLC, Atlanta, Georgia, pp. 104–126 (2007).</ref> Before Spurrier returned to Gainesville, the Gators had never won a [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC) or national football championship; before Spurrier resigned to seek a coaching position in the [[National Football League]] in January 2002, the Gators would win six SEC titles, play for two national championships, and win one in [[Florida Gators football, 1990–1999#1996|1996]].<ref name=carlson104126/>
During Spurrier's first season, he was able to build on the strong talent recruited by departing Gators coach [[Galen Hall]], but the Gators also reaped the benefits of Spurrier's "there are no excuses for losing" mantra.<ref name=carlson105109>Carlson, ''University of Florida Football Vault'', pp. 105–109.</ref> The 1990 season's highlights included a confidence-building 17–13 signature road win over the [[1990 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama Crimson Tide]] in [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama]], which set the tone for the remainder of the season,<ref name=carlson105109/> followed by conference blowouts of the [[Mississippi State Bulldogs football|Mississippi State Bulldogs]] (34–21), [[LSU Tigers football|LSU Tigers]] (34–8), fourth-ranked [[1990 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn Tigers]] (48–7), [[1990 Georgia Bulldogs football team|Georgia Bulldogs]] (38–7) and [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky Wildcats]] (47–15). The Gators also suffered two disappointing road losses to the fifth-ranked [[1990 Tennessee Volunteers football team|Tennessee Volunteers]] (3–45) in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], and the eighth-ranked [[Florida State Seminoles football|Florida State Seminoles]] (30–45) in [[Tallahassee, Florida]].
Even as Spurrier's new "fun 'n' gun" offensive scheme led by quarterback [[Shane Matthews]], wide receiver [[Ernie Mills]] and tight end Kirk Kirkpatrick was breaking team scoring and yardage records, defensive coordinator [[Jim Bates (American football)|Jim Bates]] coached one of the best defensive squads in team history, including two first-team [[All-American]]s, defensive end [[Huey Richardson]] and safety Will White.<ref name=carlson105109/><ref name=ufmediaguide>''[http://web.gatorzone.com/football/media/2011/media_guide.pdf 2011 Florida Gators Football Media Guide]'', University Athletic Association, Gainesville, Florida, pp. 116–125 (2011). Retrieved August 17, 2011.</ref> Matthews finished the season with 2,952 passing yards and twenty-three touchdowns—then the most passing yards in Gators history.<ref name=carlson105109/>
Spurrier's 1990 Florida Gators, while ineligible to win the SEC title or receive a bowl bid because of lingering NCAA probation,<ref name=carlson105109/> nevertheless posted a best-in-the-SEC record of 6–1 and an overall record of 9–2,<ref name=ufmediaguide/> and laid the foundation for the Gators' run of six SEC championships and a national title during the next decade.<ref name=carlson104126/> They finished twelfth in the last [[AP Poll#College football|Associated Press Poll]].

== 1991 ==
{{Infobox NCAA team season | Year = 1991 | Team = Florida Gators | Conference = Southeastern Conference | ShortConference = SEC | CoachRank = 8 | APRank = 7 | Record = 10–2 | ConfRecord = 7–0 1st | HeadCoach = [[Steve Spurrier]] | OffCoach = Steve Spurrier | DefCoach = [[Ron Zook]] | OScheme = | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]] | Champion = SEC Champions | BowlTourney = [[1992 Sugar Bowl|Sugar Bowl]] | BowlTourneyResult = L 28–39 v. [[1991 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame]] }} {{1991 SEC football standings}}
=== Season overview ===
The [[1991 college football season]] was [[Steve Spurrier]]'s second as the [[head coach]] of the [[Florida Gators football]] team. The Gators were led by [[quarterback]] [[Shane Matthews]] and first-team [[All-American]] [[defensive tackle]] [[Brad Culpepper]].<ref name=carlson107108>Carlson, ''University of Florida Football Vault'', pp. 107–108.</ref> The highlights of the season included dominating [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC) victories over the seventeenth-ranked [[1991 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama Crimson Tide]] (35–0), twenty-first-ranked [[Mississippi State Bulldogs football|Mississippi State Bulldogs]] (29–7), [[1991 LSU Tigers football team|LSU Tigers]] (16–0), fourth-ranked [[1991 Tennessee Volunteers football team|Tennessee Volunteers]] (35–18), [[1991 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn Tigers]] (31–10) and twenty-third-ranked [[1991 Georgia Bulldogs football team|Georgia Bulldogs]] (45–13), a hardfought win over the [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky Wildcats]] (35–26) to clinch the Gators' first officially recognized SEC championship, and an upset of the third-ranked [[1991 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State Seminoles]] (14–9).<ref name=ufmediaguide/> The 1991 season also included a disappointing 38–21 road loss to the seventeenth-ranked [[1991 Syracuse Orange football team|Syracuse Orangemen]] in the [[Carrier Dome]].<ref name=ufmediaguide/>
Among the Gators' 1991 victories, the 14–9 defensive upset of the Florida State Seminoles was a particularly memorable victory played in front of an overflow home crowd at [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]]. The Gators scored touchdowns on a first-quarter run by tailback [[Errict Rhett]], and a 72-yard bomb from Shane Matthews to [[wide receiver]] Harrison Houston in the third quarter, and held on to win. Gators [[defensive end]]s [[Darren Mickell]] and Harvey Thomas kept Seminoles quarterback [[Casey Weldon]] off balance and on the run in the second half, and, in the fourth quarter, Gators [[Safety (American and Canadian football position)|safeties]] Will White and Del Speer combined to break up a fourth-down pass to the end zone by Weldon, thus saving the victory for Florida.
Spurrier's 1991 Florida Gators compiled the first-ever ten-win season in program history, an overall record of 10–2 and a perfect SEC record of 7–0.<ref name=ufmediaguide/> The Gators closed out their season with their first New Year's Day bowl appearance since [[1974 Florida Gators football team|1974]], a 28–39 defeat by the [[1991 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|Notre Dame Fighting Irish]] in the [[1992 Sugar Bowl|Sugar Bowl]], and were ranked seventh in the final [[Associated Press]] Poll.<ref name=ufmediaguide/>

== 1992 ==
{{Infobox NCAA team season | Year = 1992 | Team = Florida Gators | Conference = Southeastern Conference | Division = Eastern Division | ShortConference = SEC | CoachRank = 11 | APRank = 10 | Record = 9–4 | ConfRecord = 6–2 1st East | HeadCoach = [[Steve Spurrier]] | OffCoach = Steve Spurrier | DefCoach = [[Ron Zook]] | OScheme = | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]] | Champion = SEC Eastern Division Champions | BowlTourney = {{alternate links|1992 Gator Bowl|Gator Bowl|title=Gator Bowl}} | BowlTourneyResult = W 27–10 v. {{cfb link|year=1992|team=NC State Wolfpack|title=North Carolina State}} | ConfChamp = [[1992 SEC Championship Game|SEC Championship Game]] | ConfChampResult = L 21–28 vs. [[1992 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]] }}
=== Season overview ===
The [[1992 college football season]] was [[Steve Spurrier]]'s third as the [[Florida Gators football]] team's [[head coach]], and the wins were harder to come by as the star-studded senior classes from 1990 and 1991 had graduated. The Gators racked up six tough [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC) wins over the [[Kentucky Wildcats football|Kentucky Wildcats]] (35–19), [[LSU Tigers football|LSU Tigers]] (28–21), [[1992 Auburn Tigers football team|Auburn Tigers]] (24–9), seventh-ranked [[1992 Georgia Bulldogs football team|Georgia Bulldogs]] (26–24), [[1992 South Carolina Gamecocks football team|South Carolina Gamecocks]] (14–9), and [[Vanderbilt Commodores football|Vanderbilt Commodores]] (41–21). They also suffered two crushing SEC losses to the fourteenth-ranked [[1992 Tennessee Volunteers football team|Tennessee Volunteers]] (14–31) in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], and the twenty-fourth-ranked [[Mississippi State Bulldogs football|Mississippi State Bulldogs]] (6–30) on a Thursday night in [[Starkville, Mississippi]].
The Gators' non-conference schedule included a [[homecoming]] victory over the [[Louisville Cardinals football|Louisville Cardinals]] (31–17), and another surprisingly difficult win over [[Southern Miss Golden Eagles football|Southern Mississippi Golden Eagles]] (24–20). They closed their regular season with a road loss to the third-ranked [[1992 Florida State Seminoles football team|Florida State Seminoles]] (24–45) in [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]].
The Gators finished their SEC schedule with a 6–2 conference record, placing first among the six teams of the new SEC Eastern Division and earning a berth in the first-ever [[1992 SEC Championship Game|SEC Championship Game]] in [[Birmingham, Alabama]]. Spurrier's scrappy young Gators, however, fell short against the SEC Western Division champion, the second-ranked [[1992 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama Crimson Tide]] (21–28). The Crimson Tide would later defeat the [[Miami Hurricanes football|Miami Hurricanes]] in the [[1993 Sugar Bowl|Sugar Bowl]] to win the 1992 national championship.
Spurrier's 1992 Florida Gators posted a 9–4 overall record, concluding their season with a victory over the twelfth-ranked [[NC State Wolfpack football|North Carolina State Wolfpack]] (27–10) in the [[Gator Bowl]], and ranking tenth in the final [[AP Poll#College football|Associated Press Poll]].<ref name=ufmediaguide/>

== 1993 ==
{{Infobox NCAA team season | Year = 1993 | Team = Florida Gators | Conference = Southeastern Conference | Division = Eastern Division | ShortConference = SEC | CoachRank = 4 | APRank = 5 | Record = 11–2 | ConfRecord = 7–1 1st | HeadCoach = [[Steve Spurrier]] | OffCoach = Steve Spurrier | DefCoach = [[Ron Zook]] | OScheme = | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]] | Champion = SEC Champions<br>SEC Eastern Division Champions | BowlTourney = {{alternate links|1994 Sugar Bowl|Sugar Bowl|title=Sugar Bowl}} | BowlTourneyResult = W 41–7 v. [[1993 West Virginia Mountaineers football team|West Virginia]] | ConfChamp = [[1993 SEC Championship Game|SEC Championship Game]] | ConfChampResult = W 28–13 vs. [[1993 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]] }}
=== Season overview ===
The [[1993 college football season]] was the fourth for [[Steve Spurrier]] as the [[head coach]] of the [[Florida Gators football]] team. The players' and fans' preseason expectations for the Gators' fourth season under Spurrier were high, and some commentators began to speak openly about the possibility of the Gators making a run for the national title.
The Gators finished the regular season with a conference record of 7–1, and in first place among the six teams of the SEC Eastern Division, thus earning a berth in the second [[1993 SEC Championship Game|SEC Championship Game]] in [[Birmingham, Alabama]]. The Gators were paired against the [[1993 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama Crimson Tide]] in the championship game—a rematch of the [[1992 SEC Championship Game]]. The Gators defeated the Crimson Tide 28–13, winning their first SEC Championship Game and their second SEC football championship in three seasons.
Spurrier's 1993 Florida Gators compiled a 10–2 overall record. Although the Gators fell short of their hopes for a national championship, the 1993 season marked the first time that they were ranked in the top ten of the [[AP Poll#College football|Associated Press Poll]] during every week of the season, and they were ranked fifth in the final AP Poll, following their 41–7 [[Sugar Bowl]] victory over the [[1993 West Virginia Mountaineers football team|West Virginia Mountaineers]].<ref name=ufmediaguide/>

=== Season overview ===
The [[1994 college football season]] was [[Steve Spurrier]]'s fifth as the [[head coach]] of the [[Florida Gators football]] team. Spurrier's 1994 Florida Gators posted an overall record of 10–2–1 and a 6–2 record in the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC), placing first among the six SEC Eastern Division teams and winning the SEC championship.<ref name=ufmediaguide/>

=== Season overview ===
The [[1995 college football season]] was the [[Florida Gators football]] team's sixth year under head coach [[Steve Spurrier]]. The Gators won their first twelve games of the season, defeated the [[1995 Arkansas Razorbacks football team|Arkansas Razorbacks]] 34–3 in the [[1995 SEC Championship Game]], and were ranked second in the nation, before losing the [[Bowl Alliance]] national championship game 24–62 to the [[1995 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team|Nebraska Cornhuskers]] in the [[1996 Fiesta Bowl]]. Spurrier's 1995 Florida Gators compiled an overall record of 12–1 and a [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC) record of 8–0, placing first among the six SEC Eastern Division teams and winning the SEC championship.<ref name=ufmediaguide/>

The [[1996 college football season]] was [[Steve Spurrier]]'s seventh as the [[head coach]] of the [[Florida Gators football]] team. Spurrier's 1996 Florida Gators posted a 12–1 overall record an 8–0 record in the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC), placing first among the six SEC Eastern Division teams and winning the SEC championship.<ref name=ufmediaguide/> The Gators capped their season by defeating the top-ranked [[Florida State Seminoles football|Florida State Seminoles]] 52–20 in a rematch in the [[1997 Sugar Bowl|Sugar Bowl]] and winning the national championship.

Spurrier's 1998 Florida Gators compiled an overall record of 10–2 and a [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC) record of 7–1, placing second among the six teams of the SEC Eastern Division.<ref name=ufmediaguide/>

=== Season overview ===
The [[1999 college football season]] was [[Steve Spurrier]]'s tenth as the [[head coach]] of the [[Florida Gators football]] team. The Gators returned to the [[SEC Championship Game]] after a two-year hiatus, but did not bring home another SEC Championship trophy. After losing the SEC Championship Game 34–7 to the [[1999 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama Crimson Tide]], the Gators ended their season with a last-second 37–34 loss to the [[1999 Michigan State Spartans football team|Michigan State Spartans]] in the [[2000 Citrus Bowl|Citrus Bowl]]. Spurrier's 1999 Florida Gators posted a 9–4 overall record and a 7–1 record in the [[Southeastern Conference]], placing first among the six SEC Eastern Division teams.<ref name=ufmediaguide/>
